node.title: Florida Senate passes 15-week abortion ban, sends bill to governor
node.description: Governor Ron DeSantis previously signaled his support for the proposal and is expected to sign it into law.

node.title: U.S. returns gold stolen from shipwreck and pillaged skull to France
node.description: The items include five gold ingots from a 1746 shipwreck, a gold coin from the third century and a skull from the Paris catacombs.

node.title: These are the corporations that have pulled out of Russia
node.description: Expecting tighter sanctions and public backlash, a growing list of major companies are cutting their business ties to Russia.

node.title: Woman accused of faking her 2016 kidnapping, defrauding California
node.description: Sherri Papini claimed she had been kidnapped at gunpoint. In reality, authorities say, she was staying with a former boyfriend 600 miles away from her home.

node.title: Airbnb suspends operations in Russia and Belarus
node.description: Earlier this week, Airbnb announced it would help shelter up to 100,000 refugees.

node.title: Did clues from an Apple Watch solve a student's murder?
node.description: Investigators follow a digital trail of text messages from the watch of Ole Miss student Ally Kostial.

node.title: Ukraine nuclear plant fire adds to fears war could spark another Chernobyl
node.description: The officials blamed the blaze on Russian shelling. No radiation level increases were detected and plant personnel were operating equipment, authorities said.

node.title: 1891 shipwreck found in Lake Superior: "Still beautiful after 130 years"
node.description: The shipwreck group posted photos and video with the name of the ship clearly visible at a depth of more than 600 feet.

node.title: E.U. ambassador to U.S. discusses Ukraine on "The Takeout"
node.description: On "The Takeout" podcast this week, host Major Garrett discusses Ukraine and membership to the E.U. and E.U. plans to offer temporary residency to Ukrainians.

node.title: Ukraine accuses Russia of "nuclear terror" on day 9 of Putin's assault
node.description: Russian and Ukrainian officials blame each other for a fire at Europe's largest nuclear power plant, but while that situation seems under control, the war looks set to escalate.

node.title: New Zealand Sevens sides off to Fiji
node.description: The All Blacks Sevens and Black Ferns Sevens will return to international action in Fiji.

node.title: Week in Politics: New Zealand begins to reconnect with the world
node.description: Analysis - An end to MIQ allows Kiwis to come home, the government reacts to Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the big clean up begins after the occupation of Parliament's grounds.

node.title: Airbnb accommodation in Ukraine booked in attempt to support its residents
node.description: New Zealanders are booking Airbnb accommodation in Ukraine in a bid to support those in the war torn country.

node.title: Investors worldwide spooked by fears over Ukraine nuclear plant blaze
node.description: Asian equity markets and the euro suffered heavy losses while oil prices jumped as investors took fright over the fire at the nuclear plant.

node.title: Abandoned rocket part to hit Moon - scientists
node.description: The space junk has confused experts but is soon to crash at high speed leaving a crater on the Moon.

node.title: Barricades being removed at Parliament, most streets to reopen
node.description: Police are about to begin removing barricades blocking roads around Parliament - but Wellington's lower Molesworth Street will remain cordoned off for now.

node.title: Political parties condemn Parliament protesters, praise police actions
node.description: All political parties have supported a motion in Parliament to recognise the "safe restoration of Parliament's grounds" and the selfless service of emergency services. Video

node.title: Farmer fined $35,000 for failing to care for his sheep
node.description: Warren Michael George Koberstein was convicted for failing to treat about 100 sheep with flystrike, and for the reckless ill treatment of eight others that died as a result of the disease.

node.title: Jury acquits only policeman charged in fatal Breonna Taylor raid
node.description: A US jury has acquitted a former detective of endangering people in a botched raid that killed Breonna Taylor in her home, clearing police of criminal liability.

node.title: White House backs bill requiring mandatory cyber reporting to CISA amid Ukraine crisis
node.description: The White House supports the Senate bill that requires critical infrastructure to report major cyber incidents, despite push back from the FBI and Department of Justice.

node.title: Ukraine demands ceasefire, humanitarian corridors at talks with Russians
node.description: Ukrainian negotiators at talks with Russian officials have demanded a ceasefire and humanitarian corridors to evacuate besieged citizens as invasion forces surround and bombard Ukrainian cities.

node.title: World Cup can leave a legacy for young cricketers
node.description: The eight Women's Cricket World Cup captains share a collective vision to progress the women's game in their home countries.

node.title: 10 hospitalized after fire and explosion at Maryland apartment building
node.description: The blast also displaced about 100 people.

node.title: Europe's largest nuclear power plant on fire after shelling
node.description: A government official said that elevated levels of radiation were detected near the site of the Ukrainian plant.

node.title: Russian athletes now barred from Winter Paralympics
node.description: Russian and Belarusian athletes have been barred from the Winter Paralympics following threats of boycotts by other teams over Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

node.title: Film studio proposal near Wanaka will have theme park element
node.description: A large film studio complex proposed near Wanaka also includes a theme park element, but a project director says it won't be like Disneyland. Audio

node.title: 'The best thing they can do now is pack up and go home'
node.description: Small groups of anti-mandate protesters are still lingering around Wellington after being cleared out of the Parliament precinct on Wednesday Audio

node.title: Hawke's Bay winegrowers say Omicron a 'significant concern'
node.description: Winemakers in New Zealand's oldest and second-largest wine region are worried Omicron will disrupt their busiest time of the year - the grape harvest.

node.title: Ukraine experience should not be allowed in Indo-Pacific - Quad
node.description: Leaders of the Quad grouping of countries - US, India, Australia and Japan - agreed on Thursday that what is happening to Ukraine should not be allowed to happen in the Indo-Pacific, Japanese Prime…

node.title: How will history - and the law - judge New Zealand's mothballed MIQ system?
node.description: Opinion - As the MIQ system winds down the outcome of the court battle over border restrictions is now moot - but the principles are still important, two lawyers say.
